sen.j: おでん（御田）は、日本料理のうち、煮物料理の一種。
sen.e: Oden is a type of boiled and seasoned food in Japanese cuisine.

sen.j: 家庭料理では鍋料理にも分類される。

sen.j: 出汁を醤油等で味付けしたつゆに、ダイコン、竹輪、コンニャク、ゆで卵など様々な具材を入れて煮込んだ料理である。
sen.e: It is a dish made by boiling and seasoning daikon (Japanese radish), chikuwa (fish sausage), konjac, boiled eggs, and so on in soup stock flavored with soy sauce and other seasonings.

sen.j: 室町時代に出現した味噌田楽、田楽と言われる食物が原型である。
sen.e: The prototype of Oden is dishes called Misodengaku (skewered and roasted tofu with miso coating) and Dengaku (grilled foods such as tofu, konjac or egg plants are fixed on skewers).

sen.j: 古く田楽と呼ばれた料理には、具を串刺しにして焼いた「焼き田楽」のほか、具を茹でた煮込み田楽があった。
sen.e: The dishes that had been called Dengaku in the olden times included Nikomi Dengaku (Boiled Dengaku), in which ingredients are boiled, as well as Yaki Dengaku (Grilled Dengaku), in which skewered ingredients are grilled.

sen.j: のち、煮込み田楽が女房言葉で田楽の「でん」に接頭語「お」を付けた「おでん」と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: Later on, Nikomi Dengaku came to be called 'Oden,' a term consisting of 'den' as in Dengaku and 'o,' which is a prefix used in lady's language.

sen.j: 江戸時代に濃口醤油が発明され、江戸では醤油味の濃い出汁で煮た「おでん」が作られるようになった。
sen.e: Dark-colored soy sauce was developed in the Edo period, which caused 'Oden' boiled and seasoned in soy sauce-flavored thick soup stock to be made in Edo.

sen.j: それが上方に伝わり「関東炊き」や「関東煮（かんとだき）」と呼ばれるようになった（関東煮の語源については「かんとうふ煮」説や中国の煮込み料理に由来する「広東煮」説もある）。
sen.e: This Oden spread to Kamigata (Kyoto and Osaka area), where it came to be called 'Kanto daki' (関東炊き) (Kanto-style boiled food) or 'Kanto daki' (関東煮) (the possible origins of the latter 'Kanto daki' are said to be 'Kantofu ni' (squids, octopuses, and other ingredients boiled and seasoned with soy sauce) or 'Canton ni').

sen.e: Kanto daki' (関東煮) has changed by itself, the changes including the use of soup stock made from konbu (a kind of kelp used for Japanese soup stock), whale, or cow line meat, and the use of light-colored soy sauce.

sen.j: その後関東のおでんは廃れていくが、関東大震災（1923年）の時、関西から救援に来た人たちの炊き出しで「関東煮」が振る舞われたことから東京でもおでんが復活することになる。
sen.e: Although Oden in Kanto became out of fashion afterward, when the Great Kanto Earthquake occurred in 1923, 'Kanto daki' (関東煮) was distributed by volunteers from Kansai, which led to the re-establishment of Oden in Tokyo.

sen.e: In South Korea, Oden is used as a general name for paste products, which are stewed in soy sauce-based soup stock (In most cases, no other ingredients are included unlike Japan) or fried with karashi miso (miso mixed with mustard).

sen.j: 上海市の日系コンビニエンスストアなどでもおでんが売られているが、串に刺し、使い捨てのコップに入れて売るという違いがある。
sen.e: Japanese convenience stores in Shanghai City also sell Oden; however, the difference is that the ingredients are skewered and put in a disposable cup when sold.

sen.j: 上海では「熬点」と書いて「Aódiǎn」と発音するが、語源は日本語の「おでん」で、煮込んだスナックというような字義をかけてある。
sen.e: In Shanghai, Oden is written as '熬点' and pronounced as 'Aódiǎn;' however, the origin of the term is 'Oden' in Japanese and the characters used have a second meaning close to 'stewed snack.'

sen.j: タイ王国の日系コンビニエンスストアでもほぼ日本と同じスタイルでおでんが多く売られている。
sen.e: Many Japanese convenience stores in the Kingdom of Thailand also sell Oden in a mostly similar style to Japanese one.
